bestBHT.bht: Peter defended his actions by recounting the events and was supported by the six brethren who accompanied him. He made no mention of Cornelius' high position, focusing solely on the uncircumcised man to whom he had been sent. Peter emphasized that he entered into the man's house without doubting or making any distinction, as per the original sense of the verb. These six brethren served as witnesses for Peter and themselves, for they had committed the same offense.

Henry Alford: 12. these six brethren] They had accompanied him to Jerusalem, and were there to substantiate the facts, as far as they had witnessed them.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: No mention of Cornelius' name, much less of his high position, as if that affected the question.
To the charge, 'Thou wentest in to men uncircumcised,' he simply speaks of the uncircumcised 'man' to whom he had been divinely sent.
Marvin Vincent: Nothing doubting... making no distinction, taking the verb in its original sense, which is to separate or distinguish... doubting being a common rendering in the New Testament and giving a perfectly good sense here."
It was natural that Peter should hesitate.

The six brethren. The men of Joppa who had gone with Peter to Cornelius, and had accompanied him also to Jerusalem, either as witnesses for him or for their own vindication, since they had committed the same offense.
Philip Schaff: Moreover these six brethren accompanied me...showing how deep an impression had been made by the recent events at Caesarea and Joppa.
St. Peter simply terms Cornelius 'the man'...These particulars would have been positively distasteful to his Jewish listeners.
There was much point in his saying, however briefly, that he 'entered into the man's house.' This was the very ground of the censure under which Peter had fallen.
Archibald T. Robertson: We entered into the man's house.
John Gill: And the Spirit bade me go with them, nothing doubting."
Moreover, these six brethren accompanied me... to be witnesses for him, of what they had seen and heard, which was a very wise and prudential step."
And we entered into the man's house; the house of Cornelius, for entering into whose house they were contending with him, and where he entered not alone, but the six brethren with him.

bhtAttempts.bht: Peter defended his actions by recounting the events that took place, supported by the six brethren who had accompanied him to Jerusalem. He deliberately avoided mentioning Cornelius by name or highlighting his high position, as it was irrelevant to the matter at hand. Instead, he referred to him simply as the man, emphasizing that he had been divinely sent to the uncircumcised. Peter clarified that he had entered into the man's house, not making any distinction or doubting the Spirit's instruction. These six brethren served as witnesses not only for Peter but also for themselves, as they had committed the same offense. Overall, Peter's testimony aimed to justify his actions and address the criticism he faced for associating with the uncircumcised.

Peter defended himself by recounting the events, supported by the six brethren who accompanied him to Jerusalem. He emphasized that he had been divinely sent to the uncircumcised, referring to Cornelius simply as the man. Peter clarified that he entered into the man's house, making no distinction and not doubting the Spirit's instruction. These six brethren served as witnesses for Peter and themselves, as they had committed the same offense. Peter's testimony aimed to justify his actions and address the criticism he faced for associating with the uncircumcised.

Peter defended his actions by recounting the events, backed by the six brethren who accompanied him. He referred to Cornelius simply as the man to avoid stirring his Jewish listeners further. Peter emphasized that he entered into the man's house, making no distinction or doubting the Spirit's instruction. These six brethren served as witnesses, either for Peter or for their own vindication, having committed the same offense. Peter sought to justify his actions and address the criticism he faced for associating with the uncircumcised.

In his defense, Peter called upon the six brethren who had accompanied him as witnesses to validate the facts of the matter. He notably avoided mentioning Cornelius by name or his high status, as it was irrelevant. Peter stressed that he had been divinely sent to the uncircumcised, referring to him as the man. He emphasized that he made no distinction, entering into the man's house without doubting the Spirit's guidance. These six brethren stood as witnesses for Peter and themselves, having committed the same offense.

Peter defended his actions by recounting the events and was supported by the six brethren who accompanied him. He made no mention of Cornelius' high position, focusing solely on the uncircumcised man to whom he had been sent. Peter emphasized that he entered into the man's house without doubting or making any distinction, as per the original sense of the verb. These six brethren served as witnesses for Peter and themselves, for they had committed the same offense.
